items.title: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
items.body:
Hello,

I'm seeing quite a long list of warnings, along the lines of:

```python
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:64: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  flag = oneOf('0 1')
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:68: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  closepath = oneOf('Z z')
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:69: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  moveto = oneOf('M m') + comma_delimited_coordinate_pairs
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:70: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  lineto = oneOf('L l') + comma_delimited_coordinate_pairs
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:71: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  horizontal_lineto = oneOf('H h') + comma_delimited_coordinates
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:72: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  vertical_lineto = oneOf('V v') + comma_delimited_coordinates
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:75: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst
  curveto = oneOf('C c') + curveto_argument_sequence + ZeroOrMore(comma + curveto_argument_sequence)
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:79: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst + ZeroOrMore(comma + smooth_curveto_argument_sequence)
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:83: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst + ZeroOrMore(comma + quadratic_bezier_curveto_argument_sequence)
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:86: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst + ZeroOrMore(comma + coordinate_pair)
/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/svgwrite/data/svgparser.py:92: SyntaxWarning: Exception creating Regex for oneOf, building MatchFirst + ZeroOrMore(comma + elliptical_arc_argument)
```
I was originally working with Python 3.8, so I tried Python 3.7 (see code above) to see if that makes a difference, but I am getting the same warnings.

Versions used:
- Python 3.7.5rc1
- Python 3.8.0

It's the first time I am using svgwrite; are these warnings to be expected, or can they be suppressed? I see the same warnings with the example mandelbrot and my own app, which just generates a blank page at this stage.

Kind regards,
 Dann

items.title: Invalid attribute 'textLength' for svg-element <text>
items.body:
`import svgwrite
from svgwrite import cm, mm
dwg = svgwrite.Drawing('test.svg', height=8*cm, width=8*cm, profile='tiny')
dwg.add(dwg.ellipse(center=(5*cm, 5*cm), r=('4cm', '3cm'), stroke='red', fill='none', stroke_width='1mm'))
dwg.add(dwg.text('91150100114153398C', insert=(2*cm, 6*cm), textLength='20', lengthAdjust='spacingAndGlyphs',
                 fill='red', font_family='Arial', font_weight='bold', font_size='20', stroke_width='0.5'))
dwg.save()`

items.title: Simplify example code
items.body:
Just a minor thing, I'm just having a look at this library, but I get the feeling the example is more intricate than it needs to. From the demo code:

```
import svgwrite

dwg = svgwrite.Drawing('test.svg', profile='tiny')
dwg.add(dwg.line((0, 0), (10, 0), stroke=svgwrite.rgb(10, 10, 16, '%')))
dwg.add(dwg.text('Test', insert=(0, 0.2), fill='red'))
dwg.save()
```

Why does a Drawing **instance** + calling dwg.add is required to create a line ?
It feels duplicate.

This version removes this duplicate behavior:

```
import svgwrite
from svgwrite.shapes import Line
from svgwrite.text import Text

dwg = svgwrite.Drawing('test.svg', profile='tiny')
dwg.add(Line((0, 0), (10, 0), stroke=svgwrite.rgb(10, 10, 16, '%')))
dwg.add(Text('Test', insert=(0, 0.2), fill='red'))
dwg.save()
```

Maybe it already does, but also it would be nice to group common SVG primitives under the root svgwrite namespace to simplify imports.

items.title: Licensing issues
items.body:
Hi, this is a very nice job. I would like to use this package but I need to be sure about the licensing: the LICENSE file is a clear MIT while the file `svgwrite/shapes.py` contains a clear GPL. Is this wanted? If not, could you pls correct it?

items.title: 'auto' is not a valid value for attribute 'rotate' at svg-element <animateMotion>
items.body:
Hi everybody,

like the topic already says: After having a line like this:
`dwg.animateMotion(anim_path, dur='15s', rotate='auto')`
I get a TypeError saying:
`'auto' is not a valid value for attribute 'rotate' at svg-element <animateMotion>`

While trying:
`dwg.animateMotion(anim_path, dur='15s', rotate='5')`
works just fine. I think validator2.py maybe sorting out strings? (just a guess)

The docs and the svg specs say that 'auto' should be a valid argument here.

items.title: Python 3.8 test failures
items.body:
In Python 3.8 with https://bugs.python.org/issue34160 the order of attributes for xml is preserved and not sorted like in Python 3.7. So using `toString()` now returns the order preserved results. This results in tests to fail with Python 3.8. Attached is a build log of test failures.

Thanks

[svgwrite.log](https://github.com/mozman/svgwrite/files/3316585/svgwrite.log)

items.title: setup.py in branch develop broken
paint-order attribute?  SVG2?
items.body:
#! /usr/bin/env python

    import svgwrite

    def main():
        """
        Run the program.
        """
        dwg = svgwrite.Drawing(profile='full', size=(1000, 1000), viewBox='-500 -500 1000 1000', debug=True)
        g = dwg.g()
        g['paint-order'] = "stroke full"

    if __name__ == "__main__":
        main()

Running the above results in:

    ValueError: Invalid attribute 'paint-order' for svg-element <g>.

This seems to be [part of SVG2.](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/paint-order)  Is SVG2 supported by svgwrite?

items.title: Setting `debug=False` does not reduce save times.
items.body:
I was experiencing [this issue](https://github.com/mozman/svgwrite/issues/25) and tried setting `debug=False` when calling `svgwrite.Drawing()` as suggested, yet it does not appear to have any noticeable effect on save times.

The slow time is definitely a result of calling `tostring()` during the save process.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

items.title: animateColor will removed from SVG2 and animateColor doesn't run in many browsers
items.body:
animateColor without a future - see: https://www.w3.org/2014/01/16-svg-minutes.html#item01

so i think it should be replaced by a common "<animate ... />" element.

In gecko browsers the following code don't work:
` <text id="text" x="150" y="30">
    here some text
    <animateColor
            attributeName="fill"
            attributeType="XML"
            id="text"
            repeatCount="indefinite"
            dur="20s"
            from="green"
            to="red"/>
</text>`

But this runs:
` <text id="text" x="150" y="30">
    here some text
    <animate
            id="text"
            attributeName="fill"
            attributeType="XML"
            begin="0;graphics.click"
            dur="20s"
            values="gray;darkred;red;cyan;lightcyan;green;purple;gray"
            calcMode="linear" />
  </text>`

items.title: svgwrite does not work when running script from cmd, Atom, or VS code
items.body: I installed svgwrite with pip running python 3.7.1 on win10x64 and i can only access the module directly from the python IDLE. From everywhere else, it doesn't seem to work. I have checked with other modules in the site-packages and they work, so it doesn't seem to be a PATH issue.

items.title: Expose ElementTrees xml_declaration option
items.body:
We are having a few problems because of SVG files not having a proper xml document header similar to this:
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>`

ElementTree (which I believe is what svgwrite is based on) apparently skips that if the encoding is UTF-8. There is a flag, though, that let's you force ElementTree.write() to always include it. It would be cool, if that flag were exposed by `Drawing::save()` and `Drawing::saveAs()`. That might also be a better way of manually adding the encoding in `Drawing::write()`.

items.title: No visible text in svgwrite.Drawing().textArea()
items.body:
The code below writes out a file named __no_textArea.svg__ which when rendered displays the __text__ string but the __textArea__ string is not displayed.  What am I doing wrong?
```python
import svgwrite  # pip install svgwrite

MAX_PIXELS = 1000

def make_drawing(filename="no_textArea.svg"):
    dwg = svgwrite.Drawing(filename, size=(MAX_PIXELS, MAX_PIXELS), profile="tiny")
    dwg.viewbox(0, 0, MAX_PIXELS, MAX_PIXELS)
    dwg.add(dwg.rect(size=('100%', '100%'), fill="lightgrey", class_='background'))

    dwg.add(dwg.text(text="Here is text", fill="darkblue", insert=("2%", "2%")))
    dwg.add(dwg.textArea(text="But no textArea\nDown below!", fill="darkblue",
                         insert=("2%", "20%"), size=("80%", "80%"), profile="tiny"))
    return dwg

make_drawing().save()
```
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49449460/how-to-implement-svgwrite-textarea-in-python was the closest question that I could find on Stack Overflow but that did not get answered.

items.title: Read in SVG?
items.body:
Sorry for cluttering the issues for this repo and thanks for creating this well documented resource.

Is it possible to read in an SVG from a directory with this library? I do not appear to see that feature, but just wanted to make absolutely sure.

items.title: save() is very slow
items.body:
It feels like the `save()` function is a magnitude too slow:

```py
import svgwrite
import time

size = 100
d = svgwrite.Drawing('example.svg', (size, size))

t1 = time.time()
for y in range(size):
    for x in range(size):
        d.add(d.path(d="M %d %d L %d %d" % (x, y, y, x),  stroke='#888'))
t2 = time.time()
d.save()
t3 = time.time()

print("create:", t2-t1)
print("save:", t3-t2)
```` 

The above example gives the following output (together with a ~400kB SVG file):
```
create: 0.5911922454833984
save: 22.79025411605835
```
When doing a profile of the code it seems the problem is `etree.tostring()` so I guess the issue should go there instead, but is it possible to do improve something about this in the `svgwrite` as well?

items.title: ValueError: Invalid children 'pattern' for svg-element <defs>.
items.body:
I am attempting to recreate this SVG grid example in svgwrite

```xml
<svg width="100%" height="100%" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <pattern id="smallGrid" width="8" height="8" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <path d="M 8 0 L 0 0 0 8" fill="none" stroke="gray" stroke-width="0.5"/>
    </pattern>
    <pattern id="grid" width="80" height="80" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <rect width="80" height="80" fill="url(#smallGrid)"/>
      <path d="M 80 0 L 0 0 0 80" fill="none" stroke="gray" stroke-width="1"/>
    </pattern>
  </defs>

  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(#grid)" />
</svg>
```

I am getting an error when attempting to add the patterns to the defs section.

Here is my code.

```python
import svgwrite
from svgwrite import pattern

dwg = svgwrite.Drawing('images/grid-patterns.svg', size=(u'100%', u'100%'), profile='tiny')

# <pattern id="smallGrid" width="8" height="8" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
smallGrid = pattern.Pattern(size=(8, 8), patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse", id='smallGrid')

# <path d="M 8 0 L 0 0 0 8" fill="none" stroke="gray" stroke-width="0.5"/>
smallGrid.add( dwg.path(d="M 8 0 L 0 0 0 8", fill="none", stroke="gray", stroke_width="0.5"))

# debug
print(smallGrid.tostring())

# <pattern id="grid" width="80" height="80" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
Grid = pattern.Pattern(size=(80, 80), patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse",id='grid')

# <rect width="80" height="80" fill="url(#smallGrid)"/>
Grid.add( dwg.rect(size=(80,80), fill="url(#smallGrid)"))

#<path d="M 80 0 L 0 0 0 80" fill="none" stroke="gray" stroke-width="1"/>
Grid.add( dwg.path(d="M 80 0 L 0 0 0 80", fill="none", stroke="gray", stroke_width="1"))

#debug
print(Grid.tostring())

# Add two patterns to defs
dwg.defs.add(smallGrid)
dwg.defs.add(Grid)

# <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="url(#grid)" />
dwg.add(dwg.rect(size=("100%","100%"), fill="url(#grid)" ))

# write svg file to disk
dwg.save()
```

Here is the traceback

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last): 
...
  File "svg-grid-patterns.py", line 16, in <module>
    dwg.defs.add(smallGrid)
  File ".venv\lib\site-packages\svgwrite\base.py", line 173, in add
    self.validator.check_valid_children(self.elementname, element.elementname)
  File ".venv\lib\site-packages\svgwrite\validator2.py", line 135, in check_valid_children
    raise ValueError("Invalid children '%s' for svg-element <%s>." % (childrenname, elementname))
ValueError: Invalid children 'pattern' for svg-element <defs>.
```
I've also noticed that I cannot add the final rect without a specified x, y value.  Is that possible?

items.title: Use of parametric svg in parser
items.body:
I want to parse parametric SVG and reproduce corresponding SVG file as user requirement. Can we use that fact and implement it using `svgwrite`.
Please let me know if you have any suggestions for the same.

items.title: Is `debug` the best name for this parameter?
items.body:
I'm curious about the naming of the [`debug`](https://github.com/mozman/svgwrite/blob/master/svgwrite/base.py#L49-L56) parameter on subclasses of `BaseElement`. I helped a user this week with a [somewhat mysterious slowdown](https://twitter.com/inconvergent/status/970756945937424385) of their SVG generation, which turned out to be solved by explicitly turning this validation behavior off.

The name `debug` to me suggests that this is opt-in behavior intended for diagnosing buggy behavior, so the default behavior of having this turned on is unintuitive to me. Would it make sense to perhaps rename this parameter to `validate` to better match its behavior?

items.title: Creating Inkscape layers with svgwrite
items.body:
Hi,

This is not really an issue report but rather more of a comment, feel free to close it right away :)

In case someone needed to create Inkscape layers with svgwrite here is an InkscapeDrawing class which extends the validator to recognize the required attributes:
https://git.ao2.it/experiments/svgwrite_inkscape_drawing.git/blob/HEAD:/svgwrite_inkscape_drawing.py

My use case is to create some baseline svg file programmatically with svgwrite and then customize it in inkscape; and having objects grouped into layers makes the customization a little easier.

Thanks,
   Antonio

items.title: svgwrite does not accept `values' for `fill'/`stroke' in `animate'
items.body:
The following code
```
animate.Animate('fill', dur = '1.7s', begin = '2s', fill = 'freeze',
  values = '#000000;#0000ff;#00ff00;#ff0000',
  keyTimes = '0;0.2;0.4;1')
```
does not pass svgwrite's type check. After removing the type check, the svg file generated works as expected in Chrome and Firefox.

items.title: allow white spaces in attributes
items.body:
I am trying to add multiple classes to my elements, to style via CSS, but get an error when doing so. It seems you cannot have white spaces in the attributes. Example:
```
mycircle['class'] = "class1 class2"
```
This throws an error. The workaround is to use groups, but a) that's harder and b) this still limits styling flexibility. So, I suggest allowing spaces.

items.title: data attributes
items.body:
Thanks for the great tool :)

This is a feature request. Currently the validator throws an exception for data-* attributes. Maybe attributes starting with `data-` should be ignored for validation, as SVG2 draft allows that.

* https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/struct.html#DataAttributes
* [https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/data-*](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/data-*)

items.title: ICC-colors
items.body:
Is there support for using [ICC-colors ](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVGColor12/#icc-colors) instead of sRGB colours, e.g., as part of a `stroke` specification of a line?

If not, is this a planned feature?

items.title: text-decoration doesn't accept multiple decorations
items.body:
I get the following `TypeError` when doing `tspan['text-decoration'] = 'underline line-through'`:

    TypeError: 'underline line-through' is not a valid value for attribute 'text-decoration' at svg-element <tspan>.

I believe [`text-decoration`](https://github.com/mozman/svgwrite/blob/master/svgwrite/data/full11.py#L760) should accept `types = ['list-of-name']` or there should be more strict checking. [The SVG spec allows multiple decorations.](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/text.html#TextDecorationProperty)

items.title: Load existing SVG
items.body: Is it possible to read an existing SVG file? It seems there is no loading functionality.

items.title: how to specify xlink attributes?
items.body: For the attributes that contain a hyphen I can specify using underscore. Is there a similar convention for specifying xlink attributes? i.e. xlink_title? I want to be able to specify the title for a hyperlink but I haven't been able to do so

items.title: tag 1.1.10
items.body: Please, add 1.1.10 into releases page.

items.title: text_decoration svg attribute missing
items.body:
This page says the 'text-decoration' attribute is supported:
https://pythonhosted.org/svgwrite/attributes/presentation.html

But this code fails:
```
dwg.add(dwg.text("test",insert = (0, 0),font_size="30px",fill='black',
                     text_decoration='underline',
                     ))

>>> ValueError: Invalid attribute 'text-decoration' for svg-element <text>.
```
